Phil S:
 There is a subtle way that ID advocates try to frame the debate, by
 arguing almost exclusively against atheistic & reductionistic views
 of nature. By doing so, they can firstly show how bankrupt such a
 world view is, and then secondly introduce an outside agent to make
 up for this deficiency. In essence, they separate the Designer from
 the design. The tacit assumption here is that things cannot design
 themselves or participate in their own design. Having categorically
 eliminated this 3rd possibility, they can then set up the false
 dichotomy of design vs random chance. Some will even go so far as to
 assert that "self design" is a self contradictory term, making it
 easy to dismiss it without having to address it at all.
 
 But I am proposing this as an alternative to design by a Designer.
 You must rule out self design before you can assume that all design
 requires an independent Designer. Here are some examples of self
 design:
 1) Language - There is no central master mind who designs a
 language. A nation of people design language among themselves in a
 way that makes it impossible to separate the words from the speaker.
 2) Thoughts - I design my own thoughts, but these thoughts are part
 & parcel of me.
 3) Ecology - The complex ecological relationships that exist between
 organisms in an ecosystem are best explained by the cooperative
 input of all organisms rather than by an outside agent who
 masterminds the whole thing with a specific purpose in mind.
 
 The crux of this self design is the relationship between all the
 participants, rather than the conscious intent of an outside agent.
 In each case there is an overall coherence that naturally evolves,
 without having any premeditated endpoint. Self design, such as this,
 is done in an ad hoc manner. It always has an evolutionary history
 as it occurs in steps, and it always shows signs of imperfect
 design. Languages always have grammatical quirks. Thoughts can
 always be improved upon. The ecology of nature is a hodge podge.
 This is the middle ground between the reductionistsic view of random
 chance and premeditated design by an outside agent.
